div1.p: I, Ranavalomanja III. Queen of Madagascar, send these grettings to Our Brother, His Excellency the President of the United States of America.

The wish to prove, how great is the friendship and amity that so happily exists between Our Government, ad that of Your Excellency in sendinf to Your Excellency these presents and good wishes for the prosperity of the American Republic, and the happiness of your people. It is Our earnest wish to so forward the pro- gress and civilization of my people; to so-exhibit to the World my intention to place my Dominions on that fooling pro- mised all Nations, whose policy is broad and liberal, and to so elevate the character of Our country, by a proper observance and understanding of these laws which bond and protect the various Powers; that Our voice may be heard in the Councils of Christian countires, and respect paid to Our just demands. But we are surronded by difficulties, Our steps
entangled

untangled by political differences. We do not understand and Our people threatened with all the calamites of a foreign war To who can We turn in these Our troubles, but he that Great Nation in the West who ever he been Our kind friend, who sets to the World so great an example of the success, and blessings of free civilization and who, in the rememberance of her own early struggles for independence, can, but sympathyize with Our Dominions still young in its new history. We will understand that the policy of the Republic is neither a of ggresion or aggrandizement. We will remember that all the intercourse between the many American citizens who have come to Our Dominions and my Govern ment has given us much pleasure and caused us no diffculties. We underestimate that the policy of the American Republic os the extension of commerce, the increase of learning the fostering of those manu factures that are of benefit to man, and the upholding of all those just laces that protect and make happy her citizens

We wish to benefit ourselves by these things to live in peace with all men, and to develop like industries, to promulgate corresponding law, and to bring Our Dominions in closer commercial relations with the American Republic. In earnest view of these things therefore, I Ranavalomanyaka III, Queen of Madagascar, hereby solicit from your Excellency the President of the United States, the friendship and assistance of the United States in these Our troubles. I request of Your Excellency the President the Mediation of the Republic in my present difficulties with the Republic of France. We request of Your Excellency the appointment of a committee of arbi- tration consisting of equal numbers of American, Malagasy and French-- members to discuss the causes of my present difficulties and the just settle- ment of them. We request of Your Excellency a speady reply to this Our communication that Our troubles may cease, and though your great friend- ship. We may be at peace to pursue

Our policy of advance and of civilization I have instructed my Prime Minister to communicate with Your Excellency on this subject, and to express fully in detail the desires of my Government. Given at Our Court, Masoandro, this twenty- sixth day of Adijady (twentieth of May), in the Year of Our Lord 1884 and in the first year of Our reign. Faith your good friend (signed( Ranavalonmanjaka
(countersigned) Rainilaiarivony
